name: Louis XIV
inbreeding_explanation: His significant inbreeding comes from his parents, Louis XIII of France and Anne of Austria (Habsburg), who were double first cousins. This was because his paternal grandfather and maternal grandmother were siblings, and his paternal grandmother and maternal grandfather were also siblings. This perfectly symmetrical, close-family union is the source of his high inbreeding rate.
titles: King of France ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡·

name: Charles II
inbreeding_explanation: His genetic collapse was the result of generations of Habsburg inbreeding. His own parents' marriage was between uncle and niece, Philip IV of Spain and Mariana of Austria. Looking back just one more generation, his maternal grandparents were first cousins. This relentless intermarriage meant that while a person normally has eight unique great-grandparents, Charles II effectively only had four. The result was a family tree so narrow that every one of his great-grandparents, regardless of the branch, was a descendant of the same ancestral couple from over a century and a half prior: Joanna (TrastÃ¡mara) and Philip I of Castile (Habsburg). This produced a final coefficient of inbreeding higher than that of a child from a direct brother-sister union.
titles: King of Spain ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸, King of Naples ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¹, King of Sicily ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¹, Duke of Milan ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¹
